CatDescriptText: Sara Foster, maid, Beltzhoover and Pearl Doeerzbacher, Glenshaw, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, February 20, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe in the old-fashioned "woodshed" reprimand or the "talking things over with the offender" type of discipline as regards the correction of youngsters guilty of misdemeanors?" Mrs. Foster's answer reads: "Talking is better...When kids are talked to and things are explained it is a lot better...With a beating they become stubborn."  Mrs. Doeerzbacher's answer reads: "Talking is much better.  It makes the child feel more grown up and gives him a greater sense of responsibility."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Sara Foster wearing patterned head scarf, dark overcoat with unfastened button and brooch on collar, standing on sidewalk, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Pearl Doeerzbacher wearing floral head scarf, dark knitted gloves, and dark coat with shawl collar with embroidered X pattern, standing on sidewalk, Smithfield Street, Downtown
